weatherForecast.comment: It will be markedly colder on Tuesday. At the beginning, the sun shines briefly, but soon more clouds move through, bringing around 5 cm of new fallen snow. The snow showers will largely subside by the evening. The wind will blow gale-force from the north-west with gusts of 100 - 110 km/h in the exposed terrain of the Hohe Tauern. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -11 degrees, at 3000 metres between -20 and -18 degrees.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Prone to triggering fresh wind slab.
avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is moderate. Fresh wind slabs are formed by storms from the north-west. This falls on an unfavourably built-up old snow surface and is prone to triggering. Small avalanches in particular can be triggered by a single person in some places from around 2200 metres. Take particular care in terrain traps, areas adjacent to the ridgeline, crests or summits and in gullies and bowls.

snowpackStructure.comment: The snow cover, snowpack is highly variable. In high, shady slopes, the melt-freeze crust usually consists of edged snow with no binding. Due to the overall highly built-up transformed snow cover, the potential for fracture propagation is generally low. Fractures are most possible in fresh wind slab snow, above the hard old snow foundation from early winter, or very rarely in the vicinity of crusts. The snow depth is well below average at all altitudes.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger increases slightly with more new fallen snow and wind on Wednesday.

weatherForecast.comment: On Tuesday, it will start to snow lightly in the morning hours from Lofer to the Osterhorn group and it will be significantly colder. Visibility will be limited in the north right from the start. More clouds will soon move through everywhere, with 10 to a maximum of 15 cm possible by midday. The snow showers will largely subside by the evening. The wind will be brisk to strong from the north-west. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -11 degrees.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Watch out locally for small snowdrift accumulations.
avalancheActivity.comment: New fallen snow is being transported by north-westerly winds onto mostly loose ground. The risk of burial outweighs the risk of injury from stones underneath, the avalanche risk is low.

snowpackStructure.comment: In some areas, up to 15 cm of new or wind slab snow is falling on apery ground.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger remains low despite the increase in fresh snow and wind on Wednesday.

weatherForecast.comment:
On Tuesday, there is often still good visibility in Lungau with some sun at the beginning. Soon more clouds move through
clouds move through, but only traces of snow arrive in the Nockberge. The wind will blow in exposed areas
from the north-west in exposed areas. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -11 degrees.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Rare release points and risk of injury from stones.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The risk of avalanches is low, but injury from stones and falling remain the main dangers. In
gullies and bowls adjacent to the ridgeline, crests or summits in shady slopes, there are very occasional difficult to
points in the persistent weak layer. Only very rarely can drift snow packs be triggered by individual
triggered by individuals. Avalanches remain small.

snowpackStructure.comment:
There is a below-average amount of snow and the snow cover, snowpack is highly variable in the interior. In
shady slopes, there are isolated weak layers of faceted crystals in the snow cover, snowpack
mostly in the vicinity of crusts. Due to the overall strongly built up
snow cover, the potential for fracture propagation is generally low.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger remains low on Wednesday.

weatherForecast.comment: It will start to snow lightly from the Steinberge mountains in the morning hours on Tuesday and it will be significantly colder. In the northern Alps, visibility will be limited and light snowfall will prevail from the start, while visibility in the central Alps and Lungau will often be good with some sunshine at the beginning. More clouds will soon move through everywhere, with the most snow falling from the Steinberge to the Dachstein (10, maximum 15 cm by midday). The snow showers will largely subside by the evening. The wind will blow brisk to strong from the northwest, stormy from the northwest throughout the high alpine terrain, strongest in the Niedere Tauern with peaks of 100 - 110 km/h in exposed terrain. Temperatures at 2000 m are around -11 degrees, at 3000 m between -20 and -18 degrees.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slab prone to triggering.
avalancheActivity.comment: With new fallen snow and a stormy wind from the north-west, fresh prone to triggering snow packs are formed, which can be triggered by individuals in a few places from around 2200 metres. They are deposited on an unfavourably building snow cover, snowpack. Where there is more precipitation locally, enough snow can accumulate to bury people, especially in terrain traps. Take care behind exposed ridges and ridgelines, in gullies and bowls. In shady slopes at high altitudes, there are still very occasional release points in persistent weak layers that are difficult to disturb. The risk of injury from stones is not easily recognisable everywhere.

snowpackStructure.comment: Fresh windslab snow is deposited on the highly variable and crusted old snowpack, more in the north than in the south. The connection is generally rather poor. In shady slopes, weak layers of faceted crystals are occasionally preserved in the snow cover, mostly in the vicinity of crusts. Due to the overall heavily built-up transformed snow cover, the fracture propagation potential in the persistent weak layer is generally low.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger increases slightly with more new fallen snow and wind on Wednesday.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Isolated avalanche prone locations in wind slab and persistent weak layer
